(~30m) - If time: looking at feedback from project presentations # Episode 1: Gay Plague ## Past is always prologue... :::{.r-stack} :::{.fragment .fade-out fragment-index=1} ![The Washington Post, 1981](../images/20221102095130.png){width=40%} ::: :::{.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=1} ![Infection Control Today, 2012](../images/20221102095335.png){width=50%} ::: :::{.fragment .fade-in-then-out fragment-index=2} ![NPR, 2017](../images/20221102095214.png){width=50%} ::: :::{.fragment .fade-in-then-out} ![Kaiser Health News, 2020](../images/20221102095423.png){width=50%} ::: ::: ## Reflecting on what you listened to In this [google doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1iHtIa94D2avmCJQkTfzcLYkj-IEQX28dKpA2ncio4AI/edit), answer the following questions on your own: 1. What did you find most interesting or surprising in this episode? 2. What concepts/readings from earlier in the term did your listening to this episode bring to mind? 3. What would you like to know more about the making of this episode and about this podcast more generally? ```{r} library(countdown) countdown(minutes = 10, warn_when = 120, seconds = 0, play_sound=TRUE) ``` ## Opening chapters of the AIDS pandemic are straight out of Charles Rosenberg's playbook :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} > "A true epidemic is an event, not a trend." [@rosenberg2020a] ::: :::{.column width=50%} ![1918 Influenza pandemic: An event](../images/20220907105450.png){width=60%} :::{.fragment} ![HIV Crisis: An ongoing event](../images/world_aids_day.jpg){width=60%} ::: ::: ::: ## Epidemic as a play in three acts: 1. Progressive Revelation 2. Managing Randomness 3. Negotiating Public Response ## Progressive Revelation :::{.columns} :::{.column width=40%} > Only when the presence of an epidemic becomes unavoidable is there public admission of its existence. Bodies must accumulate and the sick must suffer in increasing numbers before officials acknowledge what can no longer be ignored. [@rosenberg2020a, p.566] ::: :::{.column width=60%} [First NBC News Story on HIV/AIDS](https://youtu.be/1LKJ5ZzzL0w) ::: ::: ## Managing Randomness > Accepting the existence of an epidemic implies — in some sense demands — the creation of a framework within which its dismaying arbitrariness may be managed. Collective agreement on that explanatory framework may be seen as the inevitable second stage in any epidemic. [@rosenberg2020a, pp.567] ## Public Response :::{.columns} :::{.column width=40%} > In the stress of an epidemic..., failure to take action constitutes action. An epidemic might in this sense be likened to a trial, with policy choices constituting the possible verdicts. [@rosenberg2020a, pp.569] ::: :::{.column width=60%} [UK Don't Inject AIDS PSA](https://youtu.be/Pe9B5EDFazU) ::: ::: ## Mid-semester check-in ![Please fill out [this google form](https://forms.gle/DFVq9yAb4hSi1bqG8)](../images/20221102104727.png) ```{r} library(countdown) countdown(minutes = 10, warn_when = 120, seconds = 0, play_sound=TRUE) ``` # Stigma as a fundamental cause of health inequity ## What is stigma and why does it drive inequity in health outcomes? Based on [@hatzenbuehler2013]: - How would you define the concept of stigma? - What is the relationship between stigma and other fundamental causes like racism and SES? - What avenues for prevention or intervention does an understanding of the role of stigma as a fundamental cause open up? ## What is problematic about analyzing or addressing one stigmatized status at a time? ![Table 1 from [@hatzenbuehler2013]](../images/20221101153931.png) ## How are the health effects of stigma maintained over time? ![What is going on in this figure?](../images/20221101154514.png) ## Stigma serves to create and maintain power imbalances In pathogen groups: Can you come up with some examples - relevant to your pathogen if possible - in which disease-related stigma serves to: 1. Keep people down via social and economic exploitation. 2. Keep people in via the enforcement of restrictive social norms. 3. Keep people away as a means of avoiding contact with individuals perceived to be diseased. ## Next Time - Episodes 2 & 3 ## References
